sn12.1:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn12.1:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
sn12.1:1.7: “Mendicants, I will teach you dependent origination.
sn12.1:1.8: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
sn12.1:2.2: Ignorance is a condition for choices.
sn12.1:2.3: Choices are a condition for consciousness.
sn12.1:2.4: Consciousness is a condition for name and form.
sn12.1:2.5: Name and form are conditions for the six sense fields.
sn12.1:2.6: The six sense fields are conditions for contact.
sn12.1:2.7: Contact is a condition for feeling.
sn12.1:2.8: Feeling is a condition for craving.
sn12.1:2.9: Craving is a condition for grasping.
sn12.1:2.10: Grasping is a condition for continued existence.
sn12.1:2.11: Continued existence is a condition for rebirth.
sn12.1:2.12: Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
sn12.1:2.13: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
sn12.1:3.1: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.
sn12.1:3.3: When consciousness ceases, name and form cease.
sn12.1:3.4: When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease.
sn12.1:3.5: When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases.
sn12.1:3.9: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.
sn12.1:3.10: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.
sn12.1:3.11: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.
sn12.1:3.12: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”
sn12.1:3.13: That is what the Buddha said.
sn12.1:3.14: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
